awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Novel File Exchange Software Platform to Increase Patient Volume and Hospital System Efficiency
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of referral processing software to increase hospital system workflow efficiency without compromising patient volume. New patient appointments are important healthcare performance metrics because they are a significant revenue source and critical for strategic growth for all healthcare systems. The referral market is estimated at 2.3 billion dollars annually. In the United States, 1 out of 3 patients are referred to see a specialist every year. However, as many as 50% of these patient referrals are never completed – resulting in an estimated annual loss of $370 billion in revenue. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a software platform to process patient referrals to provide a more transparent closed-loop solution towards exchanging medical documents between two different hospital systems. The proposed technology employs machine learning algorithms to provide data analytics and insight into operational efficiency for hospital leadership. In addition, this information may be used to provide practice and behavioral recommendations to meet performance metrics defined by the institution. In doing so, the proposed technology addresses the major contributor to new patient scheduling delays and increases revenue for healthcare systems. It also may decrease delays in patient care and avoid repeating unneeded procedures and tests because of incomplete medical records.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, SAN FRANCISCO, THE

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project was to conduct customer discovery on the new patient referral process for cancer patients. We were able to conduct customer discovery interviews across 21+ healthcare centers across the United States with more than 150+ interviews. This occurred in various contexts - via Zoom and in person at meetings (e.g., Machine Learning for Healthcare Conference and the AHNS International Conference on Head and Neck Cancer).

Through this process, we were able to identify an unmet need for a software platform that is able to help facilitate document exchange and deliver predictive analytics to identify patients at the greatest health risk or with the most urgent medical conditions.Due to these activities, we could confidently map out who would be the end users, influencers, purchasers, and saboteurs for our product.  We were also able to define our customer segment and our beachhead market. Through these interviews, we have a better understanding of our value proposition and key features for our MVP.

In doing so, we confirmed product-market fit for our solution. We were also able to understand better the value proposition we could offer with our product and the milestones necessary for a pilot trial. Due to these results, we decided to incorporate and submitted an NSF SBIR Phase I application. We are proud to announce we were awarded an NSR SBIR Phase I grant.


Last Modified: 10/01/2023
Modified by: Nicole T Jiam
